subject: Art & Design
title: Japanese Fashion: Deconstructing Western Rules
description: A short lesson to help you apply Japanese Fashion: Deconstructing Western Rules.

hook.text: Rei Kawakubo sent models down the Paris runway in ripped, asymmetric, black garments. Critics called it 'Hiroshima chic.

buildup.text: 1980s Japanese designers â€” Kawakubo, Yamamoto, Miyake â€” challenged Western fashion's obsession with the body, color.

discovery.text: They used draping, wrapping, and oversized shapes that concealed rather than revealed the body.

twist.text: Western fashion was about showing the body.

climax.text: Issey Miyake's pleating technology turned flat fabric into 3D garments. Function, beauty, and innovation merged.

punchline.text: Japanese fashion didn't break Western rules.

quiz.question: How did 1980s Japanese designers challenge Western fashion?
options: They used asymmetry, oversized shapes, and anti-fit designs that didn't reveal the body
They introduced brighter colors and tighter fits
They copied Parisian couture and made it cheaper
